bestBHT.bht: The religious authorities ordered them not to make the name of Jesus the subject of their discourses, not to speak at all or teach in his name. The disciples were faced with a choice: to obey the authorities or to listen to God. But the message of Jesus was not something they could keep silent about. They understood that they were not only being told not to speak publicly, but also to withhold the doctrine of Jesus. However, they could not stay silent about the person, incarnation, offices, sufferings, death, and resurrection of Jesus.

Henry Alford: 18.] in (literally, upon) the name of Jesus; i.e. so as to make that Name the subject (basis) of their discoursing.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: hearken to you more than . . . God, judge ye.
Archibald T. Robertson: Not to speak at all (καθολου μη φθεγγεσθα). Same construction as above, infinitive in indirect command with negative μη (and μηδε).
John Gill: And they commanded them not to speak at all.
Nor teach in the name of Jesus.
The doctrine of Jesus, that which respects his person, his incarnation, his offices, his sufferings, death, and resurrection from the dead.
John Wesley: They charged them not to speak — Privately; nor teach - Publicly.
